It is the only modern language that developed from medievalNavarro-Aragonese.

While informally known asfabla("talk" or "speech"), Aragonese is also commonly referred to by the names of its numerousAragonese language#Dialectslocal dialects, such ascheso(fromValle de Hecho) orpatus(from the valley ofBenasque).
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: Aragonese originated in theHigh Middle Ages, as one of manyVulgar LatinLatin dialectsdeveloped in areas around theEbroand further north in certain spots of theAragn (river)Aragon River, as well as urban centers and monasteries. It expanded to thePyreneeson top of a strongBasque languageBasque-likesubstratum. The originalKingdom of Aragon(formed by the counties of Aragon, Sobrarbe and Ribagorza) was progressively expanded from the mountain ranges towards the South, pushing theMoorsfarther south in theReconquista, thereby spreading the Aragonese language.

The dynastic union of theCataloniaCatalan Countiesand the Kingdom of Aragon, which formed theAragonese Crownin the twelfth century, did not result in a merger of the languages of the two territories;Catalan languageCatalancontinued to be spoken in the east andNavarro-Aragonesein the west, although with blurred boundaries because ofDialect continuumdialectal continuity. The AragoneseReconquistato the south ended in the kingdom ofMurcia, which was ceded byJames I of Aragonto theKingdom of Castileas a dowry for an Aragonese princess.

The outstanding proponent of the Aragonese language was undoubtedlyJuan Fernndez de HerediaJohan Ferrandez d'Heredia, founder of the lineage and Grand Master of the Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem based in Rhodes. He wrote an extensive catalog of works in Aragonese and also several works translated from Greek into Aragonese, the first in medieval Europe.

The spread of Castilian (the language often simply known as "Spanish languageSpanish"), the Castilian origin of theTrastmaradynasty, and a strong similarity between Castilian and Aragonese meant that further recession was to follow. One of the key moments in the history of Aragonese was when a king of Castilian origin was appointed in the fifteenth century:Ferdinand I of Aragon, also known as Ferdinand of Antequera.

The mutual union of the crowns ofcrown of AragonAragonandcrown of CastileCastileand the progressive suspension of all capacity of self-rule from the sixteenth century meant that Aragonese, while still widely spoken, was limited to a rural and colloquial use, as the nobility chose Castillian as their symbol of power.

During the rule ofFrancisco Francoin the twentieth century and the spreading of compulsory schooling, Aragonese was regarded as a mere dialect of Spanish and was therefore frowned upon (for example, pupils were punished in schools for using it).
The constitutionalSpanish Transitiondemocracyvoted by the people in 1978 heralded the debut of literary works and studies conducted in and about the Aragonese language.
article.heading: Modern Aragonese
article.paragraph: Today, Aragonese is still spoken natively within a core area; the Aragonese mountain ranges of the Pyrenees, in thecomarcasof Somontano, Jacetania, Sobrarbe, and Ribagorza.

The major cities and towns wherein Aragonese speakers can still be found are as follows:Huesca,Graus,Monzn,Barbastro,Bielsa,GistanChistn,Fonz,Echo, Aragn, SpainEcho,Estadilla,Benasque,Campo, SpainCampo,Sabinigo,Jaca,Plan,Ans,Ayerbe,Broto, andEl Grado.

Aragonese is also learned as a second language by other inhabitants of the country in such areas asHuesca,Zaragoza,Ejea de los Caballeros, andTeruel. According to recent polls, though, they only make up around 10,000 active speakers and about 30,000 passive speakers.

In 2009, theLanguages Act of Aragongave recognition of "native language, original and historic" ofAragon. There are now a number of linguistic rights, such as the use of Aragonese in the public administrations ofAragon.Languages Act of AragonOfficial Bulletin of Aragon

article.heading: Phonology
Phonological characteristics
article.paragraph: File:Linguistic map Southwestern Europe.gifthumbThe Aragonese language expanded into new territories of the Kingdom of Aragon, from the 12th century until the 16th century.Aragonese has many historical traits that join it to Catalan rather than Spanish. Some of these are conservative features that are also shared withAstur-LeoneseandPortuguese languagePortuguese, where Spanish innovated in ways that did not spread to nearby languages.

list.listitem: Romance initial F- is preserved, e.g. FILIUM >langan''fillo''("son", Sp.langes''hijo'', Cat.langca''fill'', Pt.langpt''filho'').

RomancePalatal approximantyod(GE-, GI-, I-) consistently became medievalIPA[dʒ], as in medieval Catalan and Portuguese. This becomes modernchIPA[tʃ], as a result of the devoicing of sibilants (see below). In Spanish, the medieval result was eitherIPA[dʒ](modernIPA[x]),IPA[ʝ]or nothing, depending on the context. E.g. IUVENEM >langan''choven''("young man", Sp.langes''joven''IPA/ˈxoβen/, Cat.langca''jove''IPA/ˈʒoβǝ/), GELARE >langan''chelar''("to freeze", Sp.langes''helar''IPA/eˈlaɾ/, Cat.langca''gelar''IPA/ʒǝˈla/).

Romance groups -LT-, -CT- result inIPA[jt], e.g. FACTUM >langan''feito''("done", Sp.langes''hecho'', Cat.langca''fet'', Gal./Port.langgl''feito''), MULTUM >langan''muito''("many"/"much", Sp.langes''mucho'', Cat.langca''molt'', Gal.langgl''moito'', Port.langgl''muito'').
Romance groups -X-, -PS-, SCj- result in voiceless palatal fricativeixIPA[ʃ], e.g. COXU >langan''coixo''("crippled", Sp.langes''cojo'', Cat.langca''coix'').

Romance groups -Lj-, -C'L-, -T'L- result in palatal lateralllIPA[ʎ], e.g. MULIERE >langan''muller''("woman", Sp.langes''mujer'', Cat.langca''muller''), ACUT'LA >langan''agulla''("needle", Sp.langes''aguja'', Cat.langca''agulla'').

listitem.defkey: Traits shared partly with Catalan, partly with Spanish

list.listitem: Open O, E from Romance result systematically in diphthongsIPA[we],IPA[je], e.g. VET'LA >langan''viella''("old woman", Sp.langes''vieja'', Cat.langca''vella''). This includes before apalatal approximantyod, e.g.smallcapsoctō>langan''ueito''("eight", Sp.langes''ocho'', Cat.langca''vuit''). Spanish diphthongizes except before yod, whereas Catalanonlydiphthongizes before yod.
Loss of final unstressed -E but not -O, e.g. GRANDE >langan''gran''("big"), FACTUM >langan''feito''("done"). Catalan loses both -O and -E; Spanish preserves -O and sometimes -E.

listitem.defkey: Traits shared with Spanish but not Catalan
Conservative traits not found in either Spanish or Catalan

list.listitem: Latin -B- is maintained in past imperfect endings of verbs of the second and third conjugations:langan''teneba, teniba''("he had", Sp.langes''tenía'', Cat.langca''tenia''),langan''dormiba''("he was sleeping", Sp.langes''dormía'', Cat.langca''dormia'').

High Aragonese dialects (alto aragons), along with some dialects ofGascon languageGascon, have preserved the voicelessness of many intervocalic stop consonants, e.g. CLETAM >langan''cleta''("sheep hurdle", Cat.langca''cleda'', Fr.langfr''claie''), CUCULLIATAM >cocullata("crested lark", Sp.langes''cogujada'', Cat.langca''cogullada'').
A few Aragonese dialects maintain Latinsmallcaps-ll-as geminateIPA/ll/.

article.paragraph: MainAragonese writing systemsIn 2010, theAcademia de l'Aragons, formed in 2006, established a single orthographic standard in order to modernize medievalorthographyand to make it more etymological. This new orthography is used by the:an:Aragonese Wikipedia.waybackhttps://web.archive.org/web/20101011074537/http://www.academiadelaragones.org/biblio/PROPUESTA%20ORTOGRAFICA%20ACAR%20(copia%20protechida%20ta%20referencia).pdf20101011074537Propuesta Ortografica de l'Academia de l'Aragonés

Previously, Aragonese hadcitation neededThis seems to imply that the Aragonese Academy's orthography has some sort official force or some sort of preference amongst users of Aragonese, but the Academy's article here says that, at the very least, it has no recognition by the Aragonese government. In additionm the points below imply current use of the other orthographical norms described therein, whereas the content above does not comment on the use of the Aragonese Academy's norms.June 2015two orthographic standards:

list.listitem: Thegrafa de Uescacodified in 1987 by theConsello d'a Fabla Aragonesa(CFA) at a convention inHuescais used by a majority of Aragonese writers. It uses a more uniform system when assigning letters to phonemes with less regard to etymology. For example, words traditionally written withangbrvandangbrbare uniformly written withangbrbin the Uesca system. Likewise,angbrch,angbrj, andangbrgbeforeangbreandangbriare all writtenangbrch. In addition, it uses letters more strongly associated with Spanish, such asangbr[[ñ]].waybackhttp://www.charrando.com/normasgraficas.pdf20070927223602Normas graficas de l'aragonés

Thegrafa SLAdevised in 2004 by theSociedat de Lingistica Aragonesa(SLA) is used by a minority of Aragonese writers. It uses more etymological forms that are closer to Catalan, Occitan, and medieval Aragonese sources. In the SLA system,angbrvandangbrbas well asangbrch,angbrj, andangbrgbeforeangbreandangbriare all distinct. Also, the digraphangbr[[ny (digraph)|ny]]is used instead ofangbrñ.

article.heading: Grammar
article.paragraph: Aragonese grammar is similar to the grammar of other Iberian Romance languages, such as Spanish andCatalan languageCatalan.
article.heading: Article
Definite article
article.paragraph: The definite article in Aragonese has undergone certain changes that have become characteristics of dialectal differentiationclarifyJune 2015. The definite articles in Old Aragonese were similar to their present-day Castilian equivalents. The most widespread articles in Aragonese are similar to those found in Galician and Portuguese, as they lack the initiall:
The second article, auxiliary, after a vowel, is used with anr, whose pronunciation is the softr.clarifyWhat does 'soft "r"' mean? [ɾ] or [r]?June 2014

article.heading: Lexicology
article.paragraph: Examining the Aragonese lexicon shows the origin of Aragonese words from different languages that have influenced it.

The influence of other Romance languages on Aragonese is evident, especially from neighboring languages. Catalan and Occitan influenced Medieval Aragonese, and the Catalan influence continued, under theCrown of Aragon, in the territory where the languages are in contact (Ribagora), a fact that explains the main characteristics of Eastern Aragonese. Since the 15th century, the Romance language which has influenced Aragonese the most is Spanish, having been adopted in almost all of Aragon as the first language and reducing Aragonese to the northern region around thePyrenees.

Another Romance language with certain influencewhichJune 2015isFrench languageFrench, the only official language in the neighboring country. Italian loansexamplesJune 2015have come in through other languages such as Catalan, while words from PortugueseexamplesJune 2015have come in through Spanish.
Germanic wordsexamplesJune 2015came through the conquestwhichJune 2015of the region by Germanic peopleswhichJune 2015in the 5th century AD.

Aragonese also has loans fromArabicandMozarabicdue to theUmayyad conquest of Hispaniain the 8th century, and in turn, Arabic brought words from other languages, such as Persian and Sanskrit.citation neededJuly 2013
English languageEnglish, with its international importance, has introduced a lot of new words into the language.examplesJune 2015

Many that come from the second and the third declension are masculine:L'Ebro,OGllego (river)Galligo,O Flumen,L'Alcanadre.

article.heading: Pronouns
article.paragraph: Aragonese preserves the system ofcliticpronouns derived from the Latin formsindeandibi, asen'/neandLanganbi/i/ie''.

This feature is shared with other Romance languages (cf.,Catalan languageCatalanenandhi,Occitanneandi, Frenchenandy, and Italianneandci), thus making Aragonese different from other Ibero-Romance languages, which lack such clitics (e.g., Spanish,Asturian languageAsturian, and Portuguese).
En/neis used for:

list.listitem: Partitive objects:No n'he visto como aquello(I haven't seen anything like that, literallyNot (of it) I have seen like that).
Partitive subjects:En fa tanto de mal(it hurts so much, literally(of it) it causes so much of pain)
Ablative caseAblatives, places from which movements originate:Se'n va ra memoria(memory goes away, literallyIt (away from here) memory goes)

article.paragraph: LanganBi/i/ieis used for:

list.listitem: Locative caseLocative, place where:N'ibi heba uno(there was one of them), literally(Of them) there was one
Allative caseAllative, movement towards a place:Vs-be((you) go there(imperative))

article.heading: Literature
Medieval Ages
article.paragraph: At no point in its history did the Aragonese language acquire the prestige literature developed in other Romance languages from the Iberian Peninsula.

Not until the 12th - 13th centuries did Aragonese begin to be used in written documents. From this period are featuredLiber Regum'I Curso sobre lengua y literatura en Aragn: (Edad Media)(a book of general history),Razn feita d'amor,Libre dels tres reys d'orientandVida de Santa Mara Egipcaca.La vida de Santa Maria Egipciaca: a fourteenth-century translation into Old Castilian from Latin of a work by Paul the Deacon
article.heading: Early modern period literature
article.paragraph: Spanish was from 1500 the first language of culture in Aragon: a lot of Aragonese stood out with writings in the Spanish language, to the point that in the 17th century the Argensola brothers went to Castile to teach Spanish.Alazet: revista de filologa, Nmero 5

Aragonese became a familiar and village language and each day acquired popular traces. The 16th was obscure: there is no document in Aragonese, just in Aljamia.clarifyJune 2014El aragons de la literatura aljamiado-moriscaIn the 17th century appeared certain texts that used the language to characterized popular characters.
In a literary contest held in Huesca in 1650, there were three poems submitted in Aragonese, respectively, by Matas Pradas, Isabel de Rodas and "Fileno, montas".
The firstpastoradascome from the 16th and the 17th century.
article.heading: Contemporary literature
article.paragraph: The 19th and 20th centuries have seen a renaissance of the Aragonese literature; however, due to the lack of a standard language, authors write about local topics, each using his own variety of the language. In 1844, the novelVida de Pedro Saputo, by Braulio Foz, appeared in Almudvar Aragonese. In the 20th century theCostumbrismocostumbristcomedies written by Domingo Miral gained importance, as well as the poetry of Veremundo Mndez Coarasa, both in Hecho Aragonese; inGraus Aragonese, one can highlight Cleto Torrodellas' verses and Tonn de Baldomera's popular writings; in Somontano Aragonese, there are Pedro Arnal Cavero's costumbrist narrations, as well as Juana Coscujuela' novel,A Lueca, historia d'una moceta d'o Semontano.
